message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Menopause is defined as the cessation of menses for at least 12 months. Increased serum FSH and LH levels are associated with menopause but are not required for diagnosis. Increased total cholesterol is not associated with menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Menopause is defined as the permanent cessation of menstrual periods, which is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhea. Increased serum FSH and LH levels are commonly seen in menopause, but they are not required for the diagnosis. Increased total cholesterol is not a feature of menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most reliable parameter to diagnose menopause is the cessation of menses for at least 12 months. Increased FSH and LH levels can be seen in menopause but are not required for diagnosis and increased total cholesterol is not related to menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Menopause is typically diagnosed after cessation of menses for at least 12 months. Increased serum FSH and LH levels are commonly seen during menopause, but a formal diagnosis requires the cessation of menses for at least 12 months. Increased total cholesterol is not a diagnostic parameter for menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Menopause is defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation for at least 12 months. Increased serum FSH and LH levels are markers of menopause, but they are not required for formal diagnosis. Increased total cholesterol is not a reliable marker for menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis of menopause requires the cessation of menses for at least 12 months. Increased serum FSH and LH can be seen in menopause, but they are not required for the diagnosis. Increased total cholesterol is not a diagnostic criterion for menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Menopause is defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation for at least 12 consecutive months. Increased serum FSH and LH can indicate perimenopause, but cessation of menses for 12 months is required for a formal diagnosis of menopause. Increased total cholesterol is not a diagnostic criterion for menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. To formally diagnose menopause, cessation of menses for at least 12 months is required. Increased serum FSH and LH can be seen during menopause but is not required for diagnosis. Increased total cholesterol is not a parameter for menopause diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cessation of menses for at least 12 months is the gold standard for diagnosing menopause. Increased serum FSH and LH levels can support the diagnosis but are not required. Total cholesterol levels are not relevant for diagnosing menopause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Menopause is clinically defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation for at least 12 months. Increased serum FSH and LH can be seen in menopause, but they are not required for diagnosis. Increased total cholesterol is not a diagnostic parameter for menopause.
